topics.body: Today I learned there's such a thing as a fallacy fallacy.  The definition of it is that it's a fallacy believing that if a argument is poorly worded, phrased or contains a fallacy that they say it's automatically wrong.  I wonder if there's such a thing as a fallacy fallacy fallacy.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

right there on the right corner

"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e5748563687276cb290100#post_53e5748563687276cb290100

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e575ec636872492adb0100#post_53e575ec636872492adb0100
But pointing out fallacies shouldn't be the basis of a argument.

To use a analogy I'll use a example of something that's pissing me off lately,
"Automatically failing any student who doesn't pass all of the C++ tests is a good teaching strategy"
"But that's not a good way of doing it though, cause by doing it you'll be forcing more students to cheat on tests even though they were doing well on the class assignments"
"But that's a slippery slope in that you're saying that having the class hard to pass will force students to cheat and thus that means that having it to where students that fail to pass tests actually promotes people from cheating"

Two fallacies do not make a logical statement; two wrongs don't make a right, but two wrights make a plane *rimshot

topics.body:
Oh man; the Ebola outbreak is starting to take off.


In case you missed it's hit around 1k deaths and is spreading at a rate of around 20% increase a week and it's not stopping or showing any signs of slowing down.

The reason why this is bad is simple math:
1000 * 1.2 = 1200 -> 1200 * 1.2 = 1440 -> In a year we're talking a "oh fuck oh fuck oh fuck!" situation.

Anyone that has played pandemic this is the stage in between "give me more fricking dna points" and the "Oh hell's yeah; high score bitches" part.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e5748563687276cb290100#post_53e5748563687276cb290100
So if you point out that someone is using the fallacy fallacy, have you created a space-time paradox?

topics.body: What happens if ebola spreads to the US?
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e57b6c6368727f60ae0000#post_53e57b6c6368727f60ae0000
!http://th00.deviantart.net/fs71/PRE/f/2012/177/e/4/the_dream_is_collapsing_by_maximum_the_quack-d54xpba.jpg!
!http://img1.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20130612012816/inception/images/b/ba/Parisian_cafe_dream.jpg!

"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e57bf2636872654e060100#post_53e57bf2636872654e060100
Call me a pessimist, but since the countries it's hitting are poor countries with low health conditions and even with their best efforts health procedures are constantly being broken by the populace due to lack of knowledge about the virus and thus unintentionally exposing themselves to it I would not be surprised if it hits at least a couple million dead; mainly cause the quarantine procedures are constantly being broken.

The northwest part of Africa is more than likely going to just be fucking gone with the infection spreading elsewhere in the world but nowhere to such a extent.  The usa I would not be surprised if a couple hundred people die, but like Liberia or Guinea you might want to gtfo.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e57c2f63687231b0990000#post_53e57c2f63687231b0990000
[bq="Randomosaur"]What happens if ebola spreads to the US?[/bq]
Probably a couple hundred dead, maybe up to a thousand; the CDC doesn't fuck around.  The problem with the countries it's infecting right now have really poor standard of health care.

I would not be surprised if all planes to/from the countries currently infected get grounded in a couple weeks/months depending on where it goes from here.
